question: My EC2 Instance does not have the permissions to perform an API call PutObject on S3. What should I do?
choice1: I should run 'aws configure' and insert my personal credentials, because I have access to the PutObject on S3
choice2: I should ask an administrator to attach a Policy to the IAM Role on my EC2 instance that authorises it to do the API call
choice3: I should export the environment variables with my credentials on the EC2 instance
choice4: I should use the EC2 Metadata API call

question: I have an on-premise personal server that I'd like to use to perform AWS API calls
choice1: I should run 'aws configure' and put my credentials there. Invalidate them when I'm done
choice2: I should attach an EC2 Role to my personal server

question: I need my colleagues help to debug my code. When he runs the application on his machine, it's working fine, whereas I get API authorisation exceptions. What should I do?
choice1: Send him my AWS Access key and secret key so he can replicate the issue on his machine
choice2: Ask him to send me his credentials so I can start working
choice3: Compare his IAM policy and my IAM policy in the policy simulator to understand the differences
choice4: Ask him to create an EC2 server and put his credentials there so I can run the application from the EC2 instance

question: To get the instance id of my EC2 machine from the EC2 machine, the best thing is to...
choice1: Create an IAM role and attach it to my EC2 instance so I can peform a 'describe' API call
choice2: Query the user data at http://169.254.169.254/latest/user-data
choice3: Query the meta data at http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data
choice4: Query the meta data at http://254.169.254.169/latest/meta-data
